conversations.content: The Wings of Revolution: Part One
On the outer edge of North Grastaea, the small kingdom of Norn was under attack by a neighboring nation. Just as they began to give up hope, a figure descended from the sky.
It was a dragon, clad in majestic golden armor. ＂I am AC-011 Garland of Pravda's Air Force,＂ he said. ＂I have been sent here to aid you in battle.＂
The name of Pravda was known to all. Its battalion of armed dragons had interfered in wars throughout North Grastaea for hundreds of years, with the aim of ending war forever.
Norn castle was uneasy at the dragon's arrival. Some saw the benefits of a strong ally like Pravda, while others wanted nothing to do with the group of rogue dragons.
For Pravda's very existence broke an ancient law that forbade dragons from involving themselves in human conflicts.
It was a law born in tandem with the religion that revered dragons, and knowledge of it was common amongst people of the time.
Many feared breaking this law would toss the world into chaos, but Pravda continued its crusade unabated. And so came Garland's arrival in Norn.
Finally, the king himself stepped forward. ＂Your offer is most gracious, Sir Garland. But I am afraid we cannot in good conscience accept it.＂
＂Our country is small, but it is also proud. Even in our darkest hours, we have never accepted outside aid. We will not change that today.＂
Garland narrowed his eyes. ＂Your confidence is laudable— but should a king not act in the best interest of his people?＂
The king raised his chin. ＂Indeed. And accepting help from a dragon who so readily ignores the ancient laws would no doubt anger the  dragons who support my people.＂
The king then led his soldiers to the battlefield. ＂Old laws are not always good ones,＂ Garland thought. ＂And clinging to this one will spell your end.＂ He flew after the king.
The Wings of Revolution: Part Two
As the Kingdom of Norn endured attacks from a neighboring nation, a member of the armed dragons of Pravda, AC-011 Garland, arrived to offer aid.
But the king of Norn was proud, and refused the dragon's assistance. He set off for battle with only his soldiers behind him, determined to win the day by their might alone.
Arrows and boulders rained down upon the Nornians as the battle began. The odds of victory appeared slim indeed.
But still the king refused to retreat. ＂Steel yourselves and fight to the last!＂ he cried. ＂Fill your hearts with the pride of giving your lives for your country!＂
Though its destruction was nigh, the king cared only for preserving the proud history of his nation. And so his men charged forward, meeting the next wave of arrows head on.
But before they could strike, the arrows were blown aside by a sudden gale. Garland had arrived.
＂We do not require your aid, dragon!＂ the king spat. Garland turned to him. ＂Are you fighting for your country's future, or for days long past?＂
＂Our forces seek to protect the land as it is NOW. Thus have we shed the shackles of ancient laws. But what of you? Do you value the past over the present?＂
Garland left the speechless king to consider his words, and charged forth to meet the advancing enemy forces.
His wings cleaved through their ranks with ease, and with a flash he struck down the enemy commander. The tide of battle had been irreparably turned.
Silence fell over the battlefield, until Garland himself broke it. ＂Norn has the support of Pravda. If you value your lives, you will return home and issue a truce at once.＂
The air itself seemed to bristle at the word ＂Pravda.＂ The enemy soldiers heeded the dragon's words, and turned on their heels to leave.
The soldiers of Norn cheered in disbelief, while their king could only stand with his mouth agape at the dragon looming silently over the now-still battlefield.
Several days later, the invading nation issued a truce. Garland subsequently received orders to return home.
The king refused to thank Garland, to the very last. People are often reticent to cast aside principles they have protected their entire lives.
The people of Norn spoke not of their savior, or their brief disregard for ancient law, and returned to the ways of old. Garland had witnessed such regression time and time again.
He spread his wings and took to the cold, cloudy sky—but as he did, he noticed a figure standing outside the keep of Norn castle.
It was the king of Norn himself. He did not wave, or smile, or call out to Garland. He merely watched the dragon rise ever higher into the sky.
Garland smiled at this, for he recognized the proud man's intentions. He had come to see him off, in his own way.
＂I am honored by your gesture. Should this land ever find itself threatened by wanton violence once more, I shall return to offer my aid.＂
The ancient laws that govern humans and dragons may still be honored, but the winds of change appear to be picking up as well.
